summary: thor, a genius, at 4 am: but it should be called teethbrush, bruce, because you brush all of your teeth, not just one tooth that...
body:
thor, a genius, at 4 am: but it should be called teethbrush, bruce, because you brush all of your teeth, not just one tooth that would be ridiculous-

bruce, a tired bi: please go to sleep, for once

peter, stuck to their ceiling: let him finish

summary:
Peter + symbiote

"Oh, Tony, it's you." Parker appreciably relaxed and smiled. He turned to the sink and, hiding the alarm in...
caption:
Peter + symbiote

“Oh, Tony, it’s you.” Parker appreciably relaxed and smiled. He turned to the sink and, hiding the alarm in his voice, continued to say: “Sorry, I did not expect the guests.” Stark paused for a moment, without uttering a sound. It seems that he did not even breathe. Such an easy treatment instead of the usual “Mr. Stark” was unusual, but at the moment it bothered little. A lot more costume made him have a strain, red eyes made him have stress and, damn, the blood that Parker so diligently tried to wash off with made him have a strain. And the blood was clearly not his.

“Petey, you’re scaring me…”

summary: Prompt: “Don’t cry!” [Uncle Loki] I just wanted to fill some uncle Loki in my blog and did this little drabble for you all!  ...
body:
Prompt: “Don’t cry!” [Uncle Loki]

I just wanted to fill some uncle Loki in my blog and did this little drabble for you all! 

Words: 700

Crying does nothing inside the soul stone.

Sure, Peter can feel tears, but it’s all fabricated. An illusion that doesn’t make him feel closer to being alive.

Even so, Peter can’t remember when he stopped crying. He’s been stuck inside this unknown place for what feels like years. Gamora told him they are trapped in the stone.  It’s a nothing and a something. There’s nowhere to go and no place to be in this stone, but with extra practice, it’s easy to bend the small walls inside and cross over to other people’s pockets. Naturally, after some time, everyone went their own way and searched for other survivors to find a way out.

That left Peter by himself.

Alone, crying and wondering if he will be alright. To be honest, that’s how he prefers it. No point in bringing some company along to his pity party.

“My father used to tell me crying was a weakness.”

Peter yelps at the sudden voice taking over the empty space. He was positive that nobody could find him in his own pocket. He would be too embarrassed to explain why he’s sad. It would be obvious enough why. Everyone here is sad.

He moves down and sits next to Peter. He’s careful to put a reasonable distance of space.  

“But even I knew that wouldn’t have been my cause of death,” he gives a low chuckle. To himself? It’s not a kind of joke Peter could understand.

Peter remains still. When it’s clear Peter is not going to respond anytime soon, the man clears his throat.  

“I’m-”

“I know who you are.” Peter frowns at the familiar figure.

He remembers his face. A long time ago on the news. He was just a little boy, but he knew the danger and fear that this man could bring. Peter would sit by the front door and wonder if he would walk in. He would tower over the small boy. Wearing his leather boots and high-pointed helmet and ordering Peter to surrender his whole family to him. It was a silly childhood fear, but a fear that he couldn’t shake off for a good amount of time. Loki was a nightmare for New York, without a doubt. Now, he seems almost ordinary. More broken than anything.

Anyway, what does Peter have to fear anymore? He’s already dead.

“Where did you come from?” Peter says without any intent to be polite.

“I don’t know,” Loki shrugs. “I just sort of…walked in.” Loki mumbles under his breath, “was sort of hoping someone else would be here.”

“Did you get sucked up, too?” Peter casually brushes back a tear.

Loki sighs and gives a sad look.

“No,” he shakes his head. “I’m a soul that doesn’t really have a place. I’ve been wandering around and you seem to be the first one to see me.” Loki leans back into (literally) nothing. “I suppose I should stick around then. It’s not like I have anywhere else to be!”

Peter furrows his brows and glares at the demigod. While he has no power to kick him out, he puts in an effort to make it clear that he’s not welcome.

“You know mine, it’s only fair I ask. What’s your name?” Loki appears to be ignoring Peter’s harsh glare.

“Peter,” he blinks. “Peter Parker.” He says automatically and winces. Maybe telling a sorcerer your name isn’t the brightest idea.

“Peter,” Loki repeats. “Do you choose to be alone or are you like me? Stuck and unnoticed.”

Peter is silent. He wonders if honesty would even matter in this circumstance.

“A little bit of both, I guess,” Peter mumbles. “Talking to the other souls here just makes it worse,” he shrugs.

“Understandable,” Loki nods.

“It is?” Peter peers up.

“It doesn’t seem like there is much here to talk about. Conversations can easily run dry in this stone. Is that correct?”

“Yeah,” Peter sighs. “Yeah, that’s pretty much it.”

“Best to cry alone than worry that no one will be there to comfort you,” Loki says. It doesn’t sound like to particularly Peter, but the boy can’t help but somewhat agree. Loki studies Peter’s sad expression. A small part in his chest twinges at how hurt this stranger is.

He speaks without even thinking, “With that said, I wish I could tell you things are going to be alright, but-”

“Don’t lie to me,” Peter interrupts without a hint of humor. “That’s all they say to me, here.” He pulls his knees closer to his chest.

He speaks without even thinking, “With that said, I wish I could tell you things are going to be alright, but-”

“Don’t lie to me,” Peter interrupts without a hint of humor. “That’s all they say to me, here.” He pulls his knees closer to his chest.

Crying does nothing inside the soul stone.

Sure, Peter can feel tears, but it’s all fabricated. An illusion that doesn’t make him feel closer to being alive.

Even so, Peter can’t remember when he stopped crying. He’s been stuck inside this unknown place for what feels like years. Gamora told him they are trapped in the stone.  It’s a nothing and a something. There’s nowhere to go and no place to be in this stone, but with extra practice, it’s easy to bend the small walls inside and cross over to other people’s pockets. Naturally, after some time, everyone went their own way and searched for other survivors to find a way out.

That left Peter by himself.

Alone, crying and wondering if he will be alright. To be honest, that’s how he prefers it. No point in bringing some company along to his pity party.

“My father used to tell me crying was a weakness.”

Peter yelps at the sudden voice taking over the empty space. He was positive that nobody could find him in his own pocket. He would be too embarrassed to explain why he’s sad. It would be obvious enough why. Everyone here is sad.

He moves down and sits next to Peter. He’s careful to put a reasonable distance of space.  

“But even I knew that wouldn’t have been my cause of death,” he gives a low chuckle. To himself? It’s not a kind of joke Peter could understand.

Peter remains still. When it’s clear Peter is not going to respond anytime soon, the man clears his throat.  

“I’m-”

“I know who you are.” Peter frowns at the familiar figure.

He remembers his face. A long time ago on the news. He was just a little boy, but he knew the danger and fear that this man could bring. Peter would sit by the front door and wonder if he would walk in. He would tower over the small boy. Wearing his leather boots and high-pointed helmet and ordering Peter to surrender his whole family to him. It was a silly childhood fear, but a fear that he couldn’t shake off for a good amount of time. Loki was a nightmare for New York, without a doubt. Now, he seems almost ordinary. More broken than anything.

Anyway, what does Peter have to fear anymore? He’s already dead.

“Where did you come from?” Peter says without any intent to be polite.

“I don’t know,” Loki shrugs. “I just sort of…walked in.” Loki mumbles under his breath, “was sort of hoping someone else would be here.”

“Did you get sucked up, too?” Peter casually brushes back a tear.

Loki sighs and gives a sad look.

“No,” he shakes his head. “I’m a soul that doesn’t really have a place. I’ve been wandering around and you seem to be the first one to see me.” Loki leans back into (literally) nothing. “I suppose I should stick around then. It’s not like I have anywhere else to be!”

Peter furrows his brows and glares at the demigod. While he has no power to kick him out, he puts in an effort to make it clear that he’s not welcome.

“You know mine, it’s only fair I ask. What’s your name?” Loki appears to be ignoring Peter’s harsh glare.

“Peter,” he blinks. “Peter Parker.” He says automatically and winces. Maybe telling a sorcerer your name isn’t the brightest idea.

“Peter,” Loki repeats. “Do you choose to be alone or are you like me? Stuck and unnoticed.”

Peter is silent. He wonders if honesty would even matter in this circumstance.

“A little bit of both, I guess,” Peter mumbles. “Talking to the other souls here just makes it worse,” he shrugs.

“Understandable,” Loki nods.

“It is?” Peter peers up.

“It doesn’t seem like there is much here to talk about. Conversations can easily run dry in this stone. Is that correct?”

“Yeah,” Peter sighs. “Yeah, that’s pretty much it.”

“Best to cry alone than worry that no one will be there to comfort you,” Loki says. It doesn’t sound like to particularly Peter, but the boy can’t help but somewhat agree. Loki studies Peter’s sad expression. A small part in his chest twinges at how hurt this stranger is.

He speaks without even thinking, “With that said, I wish I could tell you things are going to be alright, but-”

“Don’t lie to me,” Peter interrupts without a hint of humor. “That’s all they say to me, here.” He pulls his knees closer to his chest.
trail.content_abstract:
Prompt: “Don’t cry!” [Uncle Loki]

I just wanted to fill some uncle Loki in my blog and did this little drabble for you all! 

Words: 700

Crying does nothing inside the soul stone.

Sure, Peter can feel tears, but it’s all fabricated. An illusion that doesn’t make him feel closer to being alive.

Even so, Peter can’t remember when he stopped crying. He’s been stuck inside this unknown place for what feels like years. Gamora told him they are trapped in the stone.  It’s a nothing and a something. There’s nowhere to go and no place to be in this stone, but with extra practice, it’s easy to bend the small walls inside and cross over to other people’s pockets. Naturally, after some time, everyone went their own way and searched for other survivors to find a way out.

That left Peter by himself.

Alone, crying and wondering if he will be alright. To be honest, that’s how he prefers it. No point in bringing some company along to his pity party.

“My father used to tell me crying was a weakness.”

blog.name: sentimental-journey
blog.title: the moral backbone of a chocolate eclair
blog.description: i me mar, any pronouns, pan and proud, 16, brazil

summary: how would be if scott lang and peter parker were friends?
body:
how would be if scott lang and peter parker were friends?

1. antman and spiderman would call themselves bugs team

2. peter would have cassie as a lil sister

3. ned and luiz would be fighting for which white boy is cooler

4. not killing bad guys team

5. cassie, peter, ned and scott would play with legos the entire afternoon they spent together

6. hope and aunt may would be good friends, they’d love sharing embarrassing stories about their boys

7. tony and hank would talk about science and responsibilities while antman and spiderman are burning something in the lab

8. cassie had always seen her dad as a hero, but when spiderboy shows up she would call him hero too

9. scott showing peter some magic tricks

10. scott and peter playing guitar hero and eating pizza until they fall asleep
